instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
Hey!

History for the board:

water damaged / on top of the case 
replaced <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> + <TRANSISTOR>Q3501</TRANSISTOR> - board was working fine

-> usb-c docking station connected on the side of the water damage -> dead -> 5V / 0.02A


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0V


should i just replace the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> or where to start to troubleshoot?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Also check diode mode around <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips.

Any voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
diode mode beeps on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> / 0

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> all 4 pins, 5V

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
I guess you meant "beeps".
Check if you get the same reading to ground on any big coil.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
yep, everything beeps

<CAPACITOR>C3500</CAPACITOR> looks like shit, beeps too

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
Please, STOP to diagnose by beeps!!!
Check resistance in ohm scale.

BTW, multimeters beep untill 0.050-0.070, depending by model.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
okay.

resistance is 0.02 / 0.03 OHM, almost nothing

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
Where do you get such short?
Please post accurate information...

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message: this is the resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
Do you get the same resistamce to ground on any big coil?
Like the ones for CPU?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message: on C658X? yes. can you tell me where to measure?

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
CPU core voltage is on L7211/21/31.
Also check on L7410/20 (iGPU core).
Compare ohm readings with the value on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
3 - 3.2 OHM on L7211/21/31

7 OHM on L7410/20

0.3 OHM at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message:
If no other coils give you same 0.3 ohm to ground, then is safe to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Start with 1V and increase slowly, if needed.
Set the amp limit on PSU to max.

First be sure you've checked all the coils; don't forget L9080/580.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q3501</TRANSISTOR> was causing short - crazy. this was a new chip. replaced with new one and its running.

threads.title: MacBook Pro 16" - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - 5V / 0.02A dead after connecting USB-C docking station
threads.message: If pin 1 isn't properly soldered, MOSFET gets burnt when apply power on the board.
